Posts.Content: May 21, 2010 09:30AM unlimited wrote: Keep the appt.   I had this similar situation that occured in early 2001. It turned into Mastitis and took 2 antibiotics to clear it. I was 36 and haven;t nursed a baby for 2 yrs, and never acquired mastitis when I was breastfeeding my two kids.  Once Mastitis was cleared, went in for my first mammogram.  Every was normal.  Continued to watch it over the yrs with yearly mammos. Had additional discharge again in Fall of 2003, mammo was normal again.  Had always watched this right nipple.  In the Fall 2006, one day noticed a ' dimpling effect ' near that right nipple where the ' blocked duct' occurred forming mastitis back in Feb 2001.  Dimpling or indentation of skin could imply a mass or tumor pulling etc.  Had a mammo in Nov 2006, turned out to be breast cancer ... IDC  1.3 cm  Grade 1  which is a very slow growing cancer and can take YEARS before showing up on a mammo etc.  The cancer was in the very same area where the blocked duct occured 5 yrs earlier.   It could very well be just a cyst or benign mass, but keep the appt.  I had the same as you from bloody... to leaving a yellowish crusty like residue with my night wear tops.  It also would come and go... and being aware of your breasts... will help esp when you notice something in addition such as a dimpling/indention of skin where something is tugging or pulling due to growth inside. Good luck, let us know how things pan out or if you have further questions. Hug

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2009 07:58PM unlimited wrote: SUMMERFIELD - Susan Gillespie Elliott, 44, of 6605 Horseshoe Bend Court, Summerfield, N.C., died Friday, September 11, 2009. She was a beautiful, loving, valiant woman. Her courage shone out, and we will miss her presence among us. Susan was born in Columbia, S.C., on March 26, 1965, to Tom and Sally Gillespie. Her sister, Emory, was thrilled to have a little sister. Her grandparents, aunts, uncles and cousins welcomed her into the family. We called her ‘glad eyes.' In 1983, Susan graduated from Winyah High School in Georgetown, South Carolina, with her beloved classmates. She attended Salem College, where she made life-long friends, graduated in 1987 and was selected as a member of Mortar Board. Susan savored the friendship of her schoolmates and enjoyed working in many arenas including marine biology, interior design and the paper industry. With great joy, she married Tim Elliott in 1990 and treasured the warm reception she received from his family. Tim and Susan had three awesome sons, Austin, Wesley and Julian. Together with Tim, Susan launched several philanthropic projects, most notably a medical relief effort in Kenya through their church and a creative endeavor called Peacehaven, a working farm which will provide permanent homes for adults with intellectual and physical disabilities. Peacehaven will be the future home for their son, Julian. Susan lived a joyful life. Although she had cancer, she showed us all how to live a large life that was loving and generous. She had a great appreciation for nature, gardening, beautiful things, critters, gourmet cooking, travel, art, rock music, fiber arts, sheep raising, beekeeping, mosaics, and liturgical art, and she shared these passions with her children and wider family. While Susan always had a strong religious faith, she found an impressive voice in later years. Through her impassioned speeches and her quiet acts of love, she inspired others to adopt her projects, which, with God's blessing, will continue to be beacons of light in a better world. We, Susan's family, would like to thank Dr. Gustav Magrinat and his staff for all they did to extend her life, giving us many priceless days with her that we will cherish. We also thank Hospice and Palliative Care of Greensboro for helping our family give Susan great comfort and peace in her final days at home. A celebration of Susan's life will be held on Tuesday, September 15, at Westminster Presbyterian Church, 3906 West Friendly Avenue, Greensboro, NC 27410. An inspirational concert will begin at 1:30 p.m., followed by a worship service at 2 p.m. The family will receive visitors after the service in the fellowship hall They request that memorial contributions be made to Peacehaven Farm, P.O. Box 68, Whitsett, NC 27377, http://www.peacehavenfarm.org/ Offer condolences at www. news-record.com/obituaries

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2008 09:52AM unlimited wrote: Regarding the hypothyroid issue.... I have been on thyroid meds for many yrs for an under-active thyroid.  When I started taking Tamoxifen in August 2007....... by my Sept 2007 Oncl appt I mentioned to the doc how TIRED I was  etc ---  and not motivated to do any thing.... thought maybe I needed an anti- depressant lol   ... anyways it was time to again have my thyroid levels checked and my TSH came back as a 10  ........ NO WONDER I was sooooooooooo tired  etc etc ... so he uped my thyroid meds from 100 mcgs to 112 mcgs...... this past July at Oncologist appt had my TSH levels checked and it was like 2.3 ....................  so for ME -- the tamoxifen affected my thyroid levels and I needed an increase in meds to get it back to ; normal ' levels. Might be worth asking to have your TSH levels checked -- simple blood test. Hugs

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 07:02PM unlimited wrote: I was finishing up my Taxol 3 yrs ago this month and was able to stop after 3 dd of Taxol for another reason I will discuss shortly... But regarding the TAXOL PAIN  -- boy oh boy did I also have that .... I was able to get thru 4 dd of AC with flying colors and expected a breeze with the TAXOL ....  But after the infusion around the start of day 3 and lasting a good 4 days... I had terrible bone pain in my legs. I too was on the verge of tears... wait I was crying after the first Taxol infusion and experiencing the leg bone pain   ooooooooooooooooo MMMMM   GGGGGGG ..... what did I do .... Percocet helped with the pain  didn't cover it totally but helped..... also many warm, hot baths to soak my legs also helped a great deal. Thes reason why I was able to stop after my third TAXOL is bc I was starting to develop ULNAR NEUROPATHY ....... neuropathy in GENERAL is common with TAXOL ...... and I had that in my hands and feet ...... BUT Ulnar Neuropathy is less common and could be IRREVERSIBLE ,,, and the oncolgist didn't want to risk that with me.  I have no issues now with any neuropathy.... even 3 mths out from TAXOL there was no visible sign of any neuropathy for me. Regarding my FEET and neuropathy -- for me it felt like I was walking on ice cubes ...  BUT if you were to touch them they were NOT COLD........ some ppl have the opposite effect with their feet in feeling like they are walking on Hot Coals.  What helped me with my ice cube feeling feet was to were slip on shoes in the house all the time.... slip on tennis shoes (light weight) shoe worked best for me as I'm a bare foot type of girl in the house.  Oh another help for the feeling of cold sensation feet in BED that helped was to put VASEOLINE on my FEET b4 bed along with socks. Gentle hugs to you -- let us know if you have any other questions.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 08:56AM unlimited wrote: Regarding the one lymph node that you are referring to being 'infected' ... that was the sentinel node that the dye identified  as being the first node feeding off from the breast area. I had a partial masectomy with my sentinel node removed. At that time the surgeon felt from the appearance and how it felt that it didn't contain any cancer cells in it.  Well about 3days later I get a call from the surgeon -- that indeed that sentinel node DID HAVE CANCER CELLS in it ... macrometasizes and even some extranodular extension ( meaning that cancer cells exploded out from the node)  Because of the postive sentinel node -- surgeon indicated I would need to have further surgery and have more nodes removed and tested...... From all my research, and the fact that my tumor was a GRADE 1 cancer....... I didn't want all my nodes removed out from under my armpit..... because of the increase of developing  lymphedema... So I researched and found that --- we have TWO LEVELS of nodes located under the armpit ..... Level 1  and Level 2 ............  I idicated to my surgeon that I only wanted to have LEVEL 1 NODES removed... and he agreed that would work.  Now  with Level One Nodes typically the average number of nodes found in that fatty specimen that is removed by the surgeon  is 15 average .... some women have 7  some have 20 ... it varies.  My fatty pad of nodes removed had a COUNT OF 21 NODES  found in Level One........ I still have level 2 nodes intact , But I also have mild lymphedema ( LE )...... as you can imagin when the lymph flow circulates through the body and the arm once the fluid attemps to travel up the arm to the armpit -- it gets congested -- like a traffic jam -- not knowing where to flow to since I am short 21 nodes in that area ... grrrr Since the sentinel node is positive in your mother's case --- then chemo is advisable.  I had chemo - radiation -- and now on tamoxifen since the tumor was estrogen positive.  Cirteria for chemo -- is when nodes are positive. hope this helps in some of the questions/concerns you have.  Keep asking the questions... many women are here to assist based on their previous experiences. Hugs to you and your mom.

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2008 02:37AM unlimited wrote: Revkat ( geez I had replied to this post -- long long details and about to sumit it and it gets LOST within my wacky puter) But briefly here now -- I wil lexplain what I use for my mild LE -- I have been dealing with this since June 2007-- and given a MEDI sleeve that was tight around the wrist and actually put more fluid into my hand - when my hand at that point wasn't affected yet -- grrrrrrrrr  and yes I had BOTH glove and sleeve  but being tight in the wrist area - didn't allow the fluid back up my arm  --- Anyways I use this product now -- two different sizes on for upper arm and one size for lower arm and the upper arm tubing does overlap about 4 inches on the tubing below my elbow.I also make the lower arm tubing longer to extend over my hand into a glauntlet appeareance when I don't have the need to wear the GLOVE. Its called  Dema Grip ....http://www.bandagesplus.com/catman.php?xMan=23 I love this product -- my insurance will cover it too at 80% ( Insurance Code u need to share with them is HCPC A6449 to determine if you have coverage as well. Its 100% cotton - washable in hot water by hand  u can use over and over - until the compression is lost in that cut piece.  ALways figured I would DYE the tubing to color coordinate  BUT haven't yet -- Im lucky this summer hasn't been bad  compared to last summer with heat and Humidity..... another product I found to help me when my hand is acting up -  ( where are my knuckles ! grrr )  are SWELL SPOTS  -  get the one for above the hand - it goes under the dema grip easily as well as inside your GLOVE.. I do this at bedtime - and the next morning its like  hello knuckles !!!  although my knuckles will never be a prominent as my other hand  -- but I do see knuckles  ,...  the website is --  there are other places too to get these from ... they are made in my home state of Wisconsin =)   http://www.bandagesplus.com/catman.php?xMan=23 If you need more direction on how I use the dema - grip  I would be happy to help you--- I'm happy to have found this -  it does come in beige or natural -- but I like natural --  although some ppl  think I have broken my arm -- maybe I should try the BEIGE next time  .... Hugs

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2010 07:18AM - edited Feb 9, 2010 07:21AM by unlimited Yes good question Bonnie....  Well I went into my oncologist appt Jan 25th  for my 6 mth checkup -- one concern I have always had is the fact that I wasn't having any side effects  and wondered if I was indeed metabolizing the tamoxifen   and maybe I should have that cp2yd (sp) test done. The NP went and asked my oncologist .. he steppped inside my room and since I haven't had my period for 3 yrs and typically he will switch women over to AI  after they have been on Tamoxifen for 2 - 3 yrs.  Since I was at 2.5 yrs  he said lets check your hormone levels to make sure u are indeed in MENOPAUSE  ... well the blood work shows that I am  ... big time actually  ... geeez at a tender age of just turning 45 !! lol    The doc typically switches the Tamoxifen users over to Aromasin since its close in the list of side effects  and those who tolerated the Tamoxifen should also do well with the Aromasin .. the other AIs can cause a greater increase in side effects... Aromasin is an expensive pill to take $426 here in WI ... but $15 copay works for me ... only thing I have noticed with this Aromasin in my body is stiff knees if I'm sitting.  No more kneeling  or sitting indian-style -- I'm sure will help that achiness.   and who knows if Aromasin begins to cause more issues  I can always go back to the Tamoxifen ....

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 09:28PM unlimited wrote: Well I'll share my experience.  I had a lumpectomy 12/2006 along with the SNB.  Going in for that surgery the doc only took that first node... as no other nodes ' lit up ' to be included in that sample.  Prior to surgery at the consult.... he indicated that if he felt the sentinel node was positive for cancer he would take more nodes out at that same time.  He mentioned typically a node will be hard to the touch amongst other indicators if it contained cancer cells.  AFter surgery... he told my hubby and I that he felt confident that my sentinel node was clear based on the feel of it .................  My tumor was a GRADE 1, we we knew that going into this surgery. Well, a few days later  - surgeon calls.. and sure enough the node did contain cancer cells more then what you stated above.. I also had extracapsular extension in that node too .... meaning that the cells had already popped outside of the NODE ... grrrr........... So He wanted me to go back and have more nodes removed.. In doing my research and since I had Grade 1 tumor ... I indicated I only wanted LEVEL 1 Nodes removed  NOT LEVEL 1   AND  2.  Becasue I surely didn't want to deal with lymphedema. So Level 1 nodes were removed  and I had 21 nodes in that fatty pad level ... all negative for further cancer cells   ... I healed very well from that surgery also.  But in July 2007 I developed Mild Lymphedema......     I wished I didn't have those further nodes removed, but having the extra - capsular extension ... I was probably wise to have further surgery. Typically the average number of Level 1 nodes is 15, some women have 7 some 20 .. I had 21........ everyone is different ... I still have my Level 2 nodes and the Level 3 ( located in the clavical area) So if I was in your shoes based on the .2 cm size tumor  GRADE 2  and one other node being negative I probably would say NO to the additional surgery....  Do your research, perhaps get a second opinion.  Good Luck. Hugs
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 08:27PM unlimited wrote: Well I saw my therapist on Friday 1/23.... she marked it etc ... and I'm thinking geeez she's taking in alot of fabric with her marking.  Teasing her -- I said .. I sure hope this doesn't come back too damn tight now .... lol .....  So she's like -- take off your sleeve and lets  safety pin the sleeve up on these markings....I suggested we ' back -off ' those marking a tad .....she had it marked with a 2 INCH  AMT of Fabric that would be altered.  SO pinning it up at about 1.5 INCHES..... all the way up .... I now was ready to put the sleeve on ... and it felt much better and now I too... had to concentrate and bring it up little by little ... BUT I was able to get it on and felt happy with the support it was giving my arm ..... whew.... Now I can't wait to get it back and start wearing it... it is a very comfortable sleeve from Bio-Concepts...... Its back to wrapping now ( night and day) and kinesio taping til the sleeve is returned back to me. I'm like GRACEJON -- I always allow my glove to air dry ... is the DRYER option OK ????  Thanks

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 12:06PM unlimited wrote: Nancy I was dx with IDC 11/2006... tumor was GRADE 1 ... slow growing...... yet it moved to my  sentinel node  grrrrrrrrrrrrr....... had to go back for mor surgery to remove more nodes.... I made it clear to the surgeon I only wanted Level one of nodes removed ... not to touch level 2 nodes..... typically avg amt of nodes in LEVEL ONE  -- is 15  some women have 7 some 20,,,, everyone is different .... FOR ME ... I had 21 nodes in Level ONE -- all clear of any cancer... so that was good..... And I insisted in Level one only being removed since I was a GRADE 1 tumor and didn't want chancing Lymphedema......  will I have it - and it only came on during my first week of rads.... its mild LE and very manageable................ Just be careful during rads esp initially when they have ur arms over ur head for such a long amt of time ... taking pics  etc etc .... I had asked if I could move my arms and rest them a bit .....  no no they said... well by the end of that first week both my arms were so achy... since most ppl are not use to having their arms up over their head for a long time ..... lol ... even though my arms were supported on the table it became achy and I sure felt it by the end of the first week ....  by the following week i was in seeing a therapist and that was the starting point of my LE.......and it also didn't help being summer time in the month of JUNE ....... I'm glad you have knowledge on the three level of nodes, and only had the first level removed..... continue to monitor your arm daily bc LE can start at any time  weeks  months  yrs  after cancer surgery. Good Luck =)
Posts.Title: Nodes involvement ??? Possibly, maybe, We dont know.... Mamita49 NancyD

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 10:35PM unlimited wrote: Britt... OK I will blame my craziness on ... chemo brain grrrrrrrrrrrrr OK what you have is correct, I read too much into that .2 cm of the cancer cell size within the sentinel node. See that is one piece of info I never received on my path report -- how big the node was etc - So now thinking again ....... with a 2 cm size tumor and GRADE 2 .. I probably would go forward with the node removal BUT making sure they only remove Level 1 of the nodes. Its good that you plan to get a second opinion. HUGS

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2008 11:30AM - edited Mar 13, 2008 12:07PM by unlimited Hello Suzie-- I was diagnosed 11/20/2006- soon to be turning 42 in Jan 2007.... I had  IDC ( ductal ) and was able to have a lumpectomy on my right breast and the sentinel node biopsy.  My results also indicated that the cancer cells reached my first sentinel node. I have a GRADE 1 tumor which is slow growing - less aggressive.... but yet found its way to that node.  This was Dec8 2006 ... so I too had to have another surgery to have more node removed BUT the surgeon only removed teh LEVEL ONE Nodes under my pit - since with grade 1 typically you aren't going to see a high number of invasision in the nodes......  ( we have TWO LEVELS of nodes under our armpit- fyi )  Typically the average amt of nodes in LEVEL ONE is 15 nodes  some women have 7  some have 20  -- varies --    I had 21--- yes 21 nodes in that LEVEL ONE --- all NEGATIVE for further cancer spread, thankfully.  I didn't  have this surgery until after Christmas 12/29/2006  - and during this surgery they also placed my PORT in since  with a POSTIVE NODE I needed to have chemo.  I believe that is a good call  -- to have the PORT placed  during that removal of further nodes.  I started chemo 1/23/2007-- finished mid- april,,,, then onto RADS finishing those end of July 2007.......  I did very well with everything -- few issues with the one type of chemo TAXOL -- that followed my AC txs.  Now IM popping my daily Tamoxifen pill - since I'm Estrogen positive......  So since I had that one node positive  -- that stepped me into Stage 2a----  1.3 cm  IDC   Grade 1   es /pr + , HER2 - If you have any further questions please ask -  many gals will be here to assist you and share info and tips...  I healed very well after the further node removal and was back to exercising 10-14 days aft surgery.... Most imp thing with the node removal  is little by little  increasing your full range of movement in that arm ---- Hugs to you ---
Posts.Title: Lymph Node Removal Suzie67 myheidiscrapbooking

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2008 10:27AM unlimited wrote: I would go into Urgent care  -- or ER -- Im sure they will snip the stich and pull the tube out some --- and re-stitch  - I say this bc  when I had it removed  -- The surgeon showed me what it looked like  -- and I was surprised  how MUCH TUBING was inside of me --- so I am sure they would have some extra length to work with --- Get it checked out today ---  Now ... HUGS  let us know what happens ---
Posts.Title: Drain tube broke!!! RJ62 RJ62

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2008 04:54PM unlimited wrote: Just to let you know -- when I started my rads....  I finished my Taxol last yr April 17, 2007 --- Had my port removed mid-May 2007  soon had the tattoos  - and was told I could start RADS that Tues after Memorial day  or I could wait til the following FULL WEEK -- so started my Rads on that Monday AFTER Memorial day -- so that puts me at 7 weeks from last chemo to start of RADS.  I would think you will be OK to wait til after yur vacation. Good luck with the rads  -- I did very well with them -- used aquaphor at nite time - and SWEEN CREAM  after each and every RAD tx --  begine with the creams on DAY 1 .... Sween Cream was great for me -- never once had any burn or pink coloration - just a tan boob  lol   U can get it at the walmart pharmacy -  no prescription is necessary but they do need to order it for u - comes the very next business day -- HUGS

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2008 02:08PM unlimited wrote: One more thing -- once u do get your tube fixed and  adjusted ---  when ' milking' the tube -- put some liquid soap  or lotion on ur finger tips -- to help slide ur fingertips down along the tube as u apply pressure ------ then there should be no cause for breakage ...

Posts.Content: unlimited wrote: I have had mild LE since July 2007, but have since had a bout of Celluitis over a minor paronychia finger that landed me in the hsp for 3 days with IV antibiotics back in October 2008.  Since that " blow up ' I saw an OT LE certified therapist for treatment and MLD. Received my GLOVE and Sleeve on Dec 29... had the GLOVE readjusted by BIO - CONCEPTS.........  and also now feel the SLEEVE should be adjusted especially in the area from my Elbow up to my Shoulder.  I have talked with a gal within alterations at Bio - Concepts and she told me how to mark my sleeve etc for this 30 day adjustment ....... But long story short is ....  just not sure SINCE this is my FIRST Sleeve how snug it should feel on my arm????  I sure would hate to mark the upper portion of my sleeve TOO TIGHT thus making it harder to get the Lymph fluid ' pumped' out of my arm .... So I am asking you EXPERTS ..... how does it feel when you put on your sleeve daily -- is it a real struggle to get it on .... For me using my left non- dominate hand  putting my sleeve on my right arm is so easy ... I would never need to have ' donning gloves' to get this on ....many times during the day I'm pulling my sleeve up from the elbow area - as it slides some -- and I find elephant  wrinkles gathered around my elbow area ... Its like I'm constantly pulling up " nylons ' but its my arm   LOL ................... If anyone can give me some guideline on how your sleeve feels when attempting to put it on in the morning .. I would love hearing back from you =) Thanks..........   Dx 11/20/2006, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 1, 1/21 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: LE Sleeve, How Snug??? unlimited OneBadBoob

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2009 08:08PM unlimited wrote: Thanks Otter... I have made a call into my Therapist who was the one that fitted me for the glove and sleeve. I will see her tomorrow. The gal that does the alterations at Bio_concepts indicated for me to ' mark ' my sleeve up the seam pinching at the seam marking the amount of ' extra room ' I have with a pencil so it can be adjusted for my arm. I just don't want to be ' pinching' too much sleeve fabric that it comes back being too tight! So as you indicated, Otter once your sleeve is on..... you really can't ... if you tried pinch the fabric and pull it up off your arm ?? I do have a silicon band at the top of my sleeve, my bio-concept sleeve .. has a seam all the way up from the back side of my wrist, behind my elbow to the top... and pinching at that seam I can gather excess fabric esp staring at the elbow area. This is the beginning area to the shoulder I feel needs to be adjusted tighter .. yet I don't want to pull too much excess....and have it too tight in that area. I am anxious to see my therapist Friday morning and get this resolved.... us girls spend too much time at the appts... and wrapping constantly ... to then have a sleeve be too loose and allow the arm to increase in centimeters........ thanks again .........

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 03:39PM unlimited wrote: well my timeline was as follows....  Lumpectomy Dec 5, 2006 .... Concult with Oncologist Jan 2, 2007 ...........  started chemo Jan 23, 2006 ...... However probably would have been 2 weeks eariler then that - IF I didn't have to return for surgery to take more nodes out ( that surg was 12/30/06)  -- with my Lumpectomy and SNB  I had the sentinel node positive for cancer cells..... Oncologist and surgeon likes to see the patient healed from the surgery prior to chemo being started.   I'm thinking you probably won't start chemo until the last week in Sept....

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2007 05:05PM unlimited wrote: Hello Loriann--- I had my lumpectomy last year Dec 4th, along with the SNB removal - sentinel node mapping.   however with that removal of the first node - it was found to be positive -- grrr-  so I had to have follow-up surgery to have more lymph nodes removed. This surgery was scheduled for Dec 29, surgeon was fine with me waiting after the xmas holiday. I did very well with the Dec 4th lumpectomy surg -- frozen corn or peas bags are great to assist with pain and swelling --- I was back to exercising at Curves after 10 days.  With the surgey on Dec29 the surgeon also placed my PORT in.  Saw my oncologist for the first time on Jan 3rd.......  and started chemo Jan 23, 2007. I was ready to start on 1/23 -- already had my 2 wigs picked out and trimmed to fit my facial features.  I was bald by Valentines day - but the wig was a good fit - and I felt good  - no one would know I was going thru chemo txs. The guideline generally is - for the surgical site to be completely healed prior to starting chemo.  I had 4 dd of AC  and 4 DD taxol... Taxol was added bc of that 1 node being positive  -- all remaining nodes taken on dec 29 were negative. Good Luck with your surgery, and tx plans..... come back often.. and I would highly recommend the chat room - for additional support and tips  - the chat room ladies - are wonderful and got me thru this journey with ease and comfort. Hugs

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 11:05PM unlimited wrote: I ordered my G-Sleeve today ----- Gina was awesome via email. I was worried making pymt of $9.95 and sending it via SNAIL MAIL to FL and back to Wisconsin -- I won't receive the pink g sleeve prior to my July 7th surgery. She's sending out my sleeve today and I'll send her pymt for it, since she doesn't accept credit card. I was stricken with celluitis back in October 2008 .... 3 nites in the hsp... and doing alot of educating to the nurses and NA's ......................... many aren't fully aware of all the precautions we must take. I went in for a PRE OP exam a couple weeks ago and had to have some standard blood work done for the preop etc ... usually the technicians have to use my hand to draw blood etc ( of my un-affected LE hand/arm) ... she was having a hard time finding a cooperative vein in that arm and hand .... YET she still had the NERVE to ask --- " so I really can't use the other arm at all ? " I said NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO .................................................. so with 3 hrs under for breast reduction and lift next TUESDAY -- I am soooooooo glad for the G-Sleeve option ---- Hugs

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 03:53PM unlimited wrote: With Taxol  -- if ur going to have an allergic reaction it will happen with the first  infusion ----  AND a slight chance occuring with Taxol #2... I was fine with Taxol #1   but  soon with the Taxol #2 as the nurse sat with me and we were chatting - -- soon I was  like  my back is bothering me -- kinndda achy  etc -- and then I noticed my tongue felt numb ---  they stopped the taxol   gave me  meds waitied 30 mins re-started slowwwwwwwwwwwly  ------ If you do have a reaction to the TAXOL   it then gets marked in ur medical chart so each remaining taxol is pre-medicated more so  with benedryl  etc - to prevent further issues. Crazy how the body reacts from 1 to the 2nd taxol tx ----- I hated the TAXOL Bone leg pain that would start occuring on me around day 3 - lasting thru day 6 grrr  thank goodness for percocet !!! I finished my last Taxol last -- Mid- April 2007.... ps.....  my name is Jodi too =)

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2008 10:34AM unlimited wrote: A helpful hint I was given by the fitter that I had,,, bc my wrist area was too tight etc ...  was to wet the sleeve in that area - and place a filled soda pop can in the wrist area of the sleeve --  keep that area wet -- do it for 24 hrs - and then see how it feels.  So for the upper part of the sleeve I would think you would need a bigger can bc of the diameter of that area - thinking  that a  ' bushs baked bean can ' would work - or any bigger size can of soups etc .. but the sleeve has to me wet in the area that the can sits in.   See if that will work for you.  Hugs
